text:
Dawson-2
Now I’m not enough of a research specialist to analyze why, against roost earlier
predictions,radio is showing such an amazing vitality in the face of television.
Maybe Dallas Smythe will do us a survey on that one of these days. I frankly would
never have predicted "Trend Number Two"-the fact that radio is booming.
But on"Trend Number Two"—-the evident raising of standards in radio-I’m going to
stick my neck out. I thin’- it quite likely stems from two possible causes.
First, it’s quite evident that Television has had a paradoxical effect on both
movies and radio. Movies, if you follow them at all, are better than ever-more
mature, more tasteful, more and more appealing to a discriminating, intelligent,
adult audience. And we’ve already noted the same trend in radio.
Without any figures or charts to back me up-and this, anyway, is something that
can't be measured statistically-I’d say that Television has put its major empha¬
sis on the mass audience. Correspondingly, the other media have had to appeal to
a more discriminating mature audience and are finding it profitable.
As for the second cause, here I could really be sticking my neck out, so I'll put
it in the form of a question....
But isn’t it just possible that the networks have been eyeing the educational broad¬
casters a little more closely than they would ever admit?
Ten years ago, we, the educational broadcasters, were figuratively patted on the
head and then pretty much ignored-certainly not to be taken seriously. Since
World War II, the "step-child" has grown up. I think we all realize that, slowly
but surely, without the funds to put on a continuous high-pressure publicity cam¬
paign, we are neverthe less reaching an ever-larger audience of people (not neces¬
sarily the intellectuals alone) who are finding that educational radio programs can
be exciting, rewarding listening. People who are finding, perhaps, for the first
time, that a spark has been put to the spirit, as Anatole France phrased it, and
that they have caught fire from, say, a discussion of one of the Great Books, or
an excerpt from a fine play, or a talk on science or philosophy, or a strain of
great music.
We are, in short, each of us, a potential force in our community. Our efforts are
being increasingly recognized and appreciated. The Allerton House predictions of
1949 and 1950 are coming true. So what about our program for the future?
* * * % * * * * * * *
Within present time limitations, I’m going to suggest two major point of emphasis
which apply to all of us, if we want to continue to grow and expand, influence-
wise, ih our communities.
* * * * ********
First, we’ve got to continually work toward up-grading our standards of presenta¬
tion, to meet the demands of an increasingly discriminating, adult audience. We
still,to some degree, continue to suffer a sort of hangover from the earlier days
of educational radio when we were content with relatively un-professional student-
type production and performance.
We are too often satisfied with a poor speaker as long as his subject is vital. We
compromise there. We know that it's important to do a series on child development,
say, and from a standpoint of inter-campus relations, we have to have Professor
So-and-So, who is the established local authority on child development.
